One of the best breakfast's I've had in awhile! They don't seem to serve pork here.. not that I cared after I had the awesome gravy and (dreamy creamy) grits!!!! Sooo good - biscuit fluffy on the inside but not dense; nice crispiness on the outside. The sausage gravy was herby, creamy and balanced.. clung to the biscuit and was a mouthful of bliss with the eggs. The grits are probably the best I've had which probably means they are loaded with calories. That's ok.. I polished off what my wife didn't finish up.  Her eggs bennie were great - a bit rich with having pimento cheese in there. Turkey bacon not my fave but if I get to go back, I'm doing a repeat of what I had!! Happy Tummy!  TIP: If you're ok sitting at the bar, chances are you'll avoid a lengthy wait (the chairs were comfy at the bar and it wasn't an elbow clashing seating arrangement).

Breakfast was our first order of business after getting off our red eye flight from Vegas. The girlfriend found this place through Yelp and we were conveniently already driving in its direction.  The Southern Style Biscuit Benedict was intriguing. I'm always down for some good eggs benedict. I'd say the dish overall was pretty good, though I found the biscuits to be a little dry for my taste. The Creamy Dreamy Grits were on point though. At first taste, I thought nothing of it, but I couldn't stop eating and finished off the bowl.  The girlfriend ordered the less intriguing Breakfast Bowl. Truth be told, hers was the better dish. Fried green tomatoes, turkey bacon, and two eggs served over their Creamy Dreamy Grits and topped with salsa. It was a surprisingly excellent combination of flavors.  Even though I didn't care for their biscuits in my eggs benedict, I enjoyed the hot and fresh biscuit they gave us on the side. They have this cranberry apple butter concoction in a bottle that you can squeeze right onto the biscuit. Genius!  Friendly service. Good food. Our trip was off to a solid start.

I gave The Flying Biscuit another try again today and my previous review still stands.  Overall, the food is very bland and overpriced to me. To illustrate I will assign a grade to everything I had: Coffee: "D" bitter and no good coffee aroma or taste. Tea: "B" pretty good tea.  Scrambled Eggs: "B" pretty good, but nothing stood out about them. Sausage: "D-" they don't have real pork sausage, it's chicken and not good. Oatmeal Pancake Topped with Peach Compote: "D" dense with an unpleasant texture and flavor. Peach compote and apple butter made it edible. Apple Butter: "A+" best thing about the meal. Grits: "A" very good creamy grits  I keep trying this restaurant because I really want to like it. I like the service and the overall vibe of the space and the location is great for me, but the food continues to underwhelm.

I had heard of this place a couple times from my Charlotte based colleges; and when I found myself with some time to kill I decided to give the Flying Biscuit a try. I was surprised to find out that they are a chain; I always thought it is a local independent joint. Anyway, I found myself a table at their patio and though it was only a Wednesday afternoon, they seemed to be busy. I ordered the southern style benedict without the turkey-bacon and a cappuccino - to be honest I was disappointed with my coffee. How can you possibly get a cup of cappuccino wrong? It was more like a cup of steamed milk with a hint of coffee. But when my benedict was brought out, I was a happy customer :) Two poached eggs served on southern style biscuits with a sundried tomato and basil gravy - very different from all the benedicts I have tried so far! If given a chance I would go back to try something else from their menu.  PS - Their grits are very rightly called creamy and dreamy :)

This place is incredible.  So good, my Dad and I went there back to back mornings.  The biscuits are divine.  Highly recommend you have their biscuit with their homemade butter spread.  Be sure to ask for that.  The Southern Scramble is 100% on point.  Scrambled eggs, turkey bacon and collard greens with cheese! Are you kidding me?  Pure genius.  The combination works flawlessly, as does the way in which they cook it.  If you haven't been here yet and are nearby, do yourself a favor: come hither.  You will leave filled with glee.
Our waitress tila was the best and the food was delicious. New favorite place or first favorite place since it's my first week in Charlotte.

First visit here was about two weeks ago. However, I was very disappointed with my order which was their shrimp and grits. While the grits were ok the shrimp tasted very fishy and seemed not to be fresh. It was also hard to get refills on the drink I ordered. On the positive side the biscuits are great and so is the location!

My friend wanted comfort food, and I was trying to stay healthy- plus had some dental work that morning. Went with the love cakes, and was really impressed with how good they were! Black bean cakes topped with salsa verde, feta and sour cream (plus onions but I nixed those). It was a really flavorful dish. I switched out my salad for collard greens. They were good too. My friend really liked her BBQ chicken burrito and soup. It's a cute little place and our server was very sweet. I need to go back for brunch!

I went here on the 4th of July for Brunch. The guy at the hostess stand seemed overwhelmed when we said we had 9 in our party although they weren't extremely busy. We needed to place an order immediately so headed to the bar and explained that we would be eating there once the other party members came in but needed to get an order in. There was a young lady and man behind the bar that immediately hopped to our service. They begin moving tables and everything! They placed our order and were so kind and accommodating!   Did I mention the food was amazing! I had the shrimp scramble--yum!

The interior of the Flying Biscuit looks like the daycare ran short on people to monitor the rugrats.  That is not necessarily a bad thing - but it is not for the faint of heart or people who like everything in shades of beige.  Plenty of color and loads of stuff all about.  Mind you, these are not tchotchkes you find at Chili's or decent replicas from Cracker Barrel either.  This is yard sale variety: The Good stuff.  Staff at the Biscuit is really nice, which is awesome because the food needs serious work.  Even the namesake biscuits are bad.  Very bad.  You might think they fly because they are light and fluffy.  More likely they fly when people throw them back towards the kitchen for being rock hard.  You know those steakhouses that have peanut shells on the floor?  I would not be surprised to see biscuit remnants on the floor one day if I walked in here.  Now the nice staff will bring you a "fresh" batch, but they usually are not much better than the first one.  Other items on the menu are generally decent, but not a ton better.  The one item that really stands out are their grits.  They are not your traditional stone-ground grits that get stuck in your teeth, but they are definitely worth checking out since they are so creamy and delish.  I could drink them for the better part of the day.  Yes, drink.  They are not stiff grits, but they are yummy.  Then again, it could just be to get the taste of the crusty biscuit out of my mouth.

Four of my friends and I went on a Sunday afternoon for a late brunch, around 1:00 or so. The place was very busy, and we waited about 20 minutes or so for a table which we knew would be the case anywhere at that time of day. The only downside is all those waiting for a table need to wait outside--a huge drag when it's chilly.  This place gives you a lot of food for a very reasonable price. I had the Southern Eggs Benedict, an item that was recently added to the menu (their online menu has yet to be updated to include all the new items). My food was delicious! I could barely finish it, there was so much of it, but it all tasted wonderful. I was disappointed, however, that my poached eggs were almost entirely cooked all the way through, with the yolk not having the slightest bit of run to it. Disappointing, but the food was still good overall, and our server was very nice and attentive in spite of how busy it was.  I'll definitely be going back for brunch again soon.

Amazing!!! The food is fresh and more on the healthy side. The restaurant already had a line @10 am on a Thursday if that tells you anything. The place had a cute hippy vibe about it but the food was the real star. I'm not a huge fan of grits but they were so good, I could go swimming in the stuff from there. I was actually upset that I had substituted mine for home fries lol. Their biscuits are huge and perfectly doughy. Don't miss out on either when you go.  Looking forward to bringing friends next time to share the wealth!

I had heard of the Flying Biscuit but always thought it was a "biscuitville" kind of place.  Finally I heard a bunch of comments about it from different people all in a short span of  time and decided to give it a try when my brother and his girlfriend was in town.    I was pleasantly surprised.  I loved the decor and the overall feel of the place.  The menu was extensive and the service was super friendly.    I had the fried green tomatoes with jalapeno cashew relish and goat cheese.  Wow!  Delish!  I also had a side of creamy dreamy grits.  I eat grits a lot at home and I just didn't know grits could be that good.  My brother and his girlfriend both thoroughly enjoyed their meals as well.  I'll definitely visit again!

Ate breakfast here again this past weekend. Waited 25-30 minutes for an outside table. Our name was called and as we walked up to the hostess table, another party that just arrived walked up and sat at an open table outside. Come to find out, it was our dang table we were called for and the hostess DID not ask them to unass our seats. I was pissed but wifey stayed cool and settled for a table inside.  We also had a new waitress who brought the check before we were done eaten. She came to the table TWICE before we were done and ask was the card in the sleeve. I felt like she thought we were going to run on her. WOW!!! I don't know what wifey likes about this place. Oh yeah! The gluten free menu.

This was a crowded breakfast spot. We had a 45 min wait for 4 people. This is a breakfast and lunch spot so we came around 11 am. We opted for breakfast and their menu is extensive. With so many choices, it was hard to choose.  I will say the service here is good and they are attentive. They get your food out in a timely manner even when there is a crowd.   I got the salmon scramble. It was really just okay I feel the description sounded better than what came out. It tasted good but seemed pretty basic. The biscuit it came with was not very fluffy and was a little hard.   My friend ordered the fried green tomato appetizer and that was just OK as well. The tomatoes were a little flimsy and it was more breaded than fried. The best part about the dish was the topping it had. Maybe this was just an ordering mishap but this place wasn't for me.

Awesome way to end a weekend in Charlotte. My French toast was delish w raspberry sauce, first time I've had whole wheat French toast. Biscuit was huge and I had to have it. My bacon was quickly commandeered by my boyfriend but I got another side and it was crispy. All our food was great and came out fast. About ~$45 for all four of us for food and coffees and of course 1 chocolate milk. Gotta have it. Waiter was funny, joked with us about their 80s music they had on. We got to sit on the patio and look out at the ACE gardening section next door. Loved it.

I have never had good food as this place. I got the hummus pita and it was honestly the worst I have ever had. The only thing I could actually eat was the potatoes which weren't awful. I will never return to this restaurant and I do not recommended it to anyone.

This place is too hyped up! I saw that it has 4 stars and over 500 reviews so I really wanted to try it. It was ok. The biscuits were over done and the coffee was cold. The whole wheat pancakes were very dry. I did like my poached eggs but the potatoes were not good. I would rather go to Famous Toastery than here.

We love eating here whenever we travel through the area.  I had the southern scrambler. The bacon and greens were perfect.  The grits were perfect.  The buttermilk pancakes were good. We even purchased a jar of the apple butter to take back to ohio.  Oh my goodness. Did I forget to write about the biscuits?  They are perfection.
Brunch was fun. Able to order vegan with company who enjoy meat. Food prepared well. Fun place to dine.

Service was excellent. The food was mediocre based on what we ordered. I had the salmon egg scramble which was amazing. Their grits are amazing also.  My girlfriend ordered chicken sausage which she said was pretty nasty.  I also had a half order of french toast and when I say those were the worst french toast I have ever had.  I mean it. They were nothing more than wheat bread thrown on a skillet with butter and raspberry drizzle. Nice try at making something basic look elegant. And its called the flying biscuit which would make you think they have great biscuits. Nah. The biscuits are bland at best. I'm willing to give this place another try but definitely not anytime soon.

I visited this location today 6/13 with my 9yr old and 5 month old. I must say there is nothing spectacular about it. I had the "moon dust" potatoes they were dry and flavorless, my fried egg was fried so hard I had to use a knife to cut it and the fried green tomatoes were soggy. The grits were ok they may have been better if the waitress would've brought the butter I asked for. Our drinks were never refilled and I had to flag someone down for the check. I did over hear a server saying they were short on help so maybe that was the issue. I don't think I will try it again

I tried their Southern style eggs Benedict today and they are by far the best eggs Benedict I have ever had! There's the poached eggs, bacon, and pimento cheese on one of their biscuits and it's topped with a little bit of basil. Such a great combo! It also comes with hollandaise sauce but I prefer mine on the side and as always the grades were really good. The staff is also very friendly and pleasant.

It'd be nice to eat someplace where they aren't shoving a political agenda down your throat - can't put your name in to be seated w/o a lecture & signs being shoved down your throat too! I don't give a hoot about your political inclinations- I wanted to order & pay for food! Won't ever be back!

Food was good, excellent customer service.  I split the shrimp and grits with a friend, so good. The biscuits with apple butter are great. Wasn't super impressed with the moon dusted potatoes or the grilled mac and cheese tho. And heads up, if you want the cookbook they advertise, it does have some of the menu recipes, but not the biscuits...
I came today for the first time and I loveeeeeee it. The food and the coffee were delicious. Really nice and fast service too. I'll definitely go back soon.

Everything is so bright! Decorated like 1950's grandma's kitchen...at least in the back. Ordered the hot chocolate. And that was stellar, heaps of whipped cream and chocolate syrup. Num! My bf order the biscuit, eggs and gravy....they have some darn good gravy.  I had a half order of the French toast. It was good. The wheat bread on there stood out a lot. It could've balanced a little better.  Love the music playing. Our server is this super sweet, super pregnant girl who was cheery and prompt. Her section seemed kind of large too. But gosh was she a dear. I think I would've gone 3 stars if not for the service. I'd check it out at again!
Glad to see a breakfast place that actually has the take out food as good as in store. Eggs are great grits are amazing. The biscuits are amazing as well

Went here with our office staff for our weekly lunch outing. The service was pretty good, seating open, and the menu is awesome because there are plenty of options for people with dietary restrictions (vegetarian, etc). With that being said, my food was just so-so. I did, however, love the potatoes! And even though i LOVE bread, the biscuits at this place are not my thing.

We went to the Flying Biscuit Cafe  on a Saturday around 11:30 and the wait was approximately 20 minutes but well worth the wait!  When is breakfast not merely just breakfast?  The constituents of a good breakfast contain a lot of the same items: eggs, sausage/bacon, toast/biscuit, maybe even pancakes/waffles.  the difference lies in the delivery.  thats what makes the breakfast unique.    now if your looking for a typical biscuit or bland grits this is not the place for you.  maybe Denny's is more your thing (and thats cool).  We had the "high flier" breakfast easily decided for the sampling of the breakfast options.  It has 2 eggs, 2 pieces of chicken sausage patties, a bowl of creamy grits, a famous flying biscuit dusted with sugar, and oatmeal pancake with peach compote.  all served with a side of cranberry spice jam.  we had our eggs scrambled with cheese and they were great.  the chicken sausage was excellent for both a sausage eater and made my non-pork eating guest very happy ^_^.  the grits were off the hook.  everything good creamy grits should be where you dont have to add a thing.  i would seriously go back strictly for these grits.  i was stealing them off my guest's plate after i inhaled mine, heh.  the biscuits (which are served with each entree, and can be ordered al la carte) had a great crumbly texture on the outside, and a chewy soft texture on the inside.  the dusting of sugar gave it a perfect sweet touch, made just right with a pat of butter.  should you want to construct your own sausage and egg biscuit with some jam you have the arsenal to do so.  you would be happy eating each piece of the high flyer breakfast on its own or combining them into a flavor layered creation.   finally, the pancake.  we were so full with everything preceding it, that we couldnt imagine eating the whole thing.  however, it had a great oat and nutty taste and texture.  it was great sans-butter or dipped into the warm peach compote.  the compote was a nice peach and light syrup topping but it didn't taste like it came from a can.   We had coffee and i had sweet tea to drink.  the coffee was very good and they offered all types of sweeteners INCLUDING a cleverly disguised bowel of lump sugar at the table!  the sweet tea was ON POINT.  this is proper fucking sweet tea.  if seriously sweet tea makes you squeamish, dont order this.  it will give you the shakes and i dont want any arrhythmia on my conscience.      our waiter was Daniel and was extremely polite, attentive and ready to please.  As stated in the other reviews this is the most interesting eclectic, artsy and inspiring breakfast place.  gazing up at the ceiling tiles made me rethink my own plain acoustic tiles back home.  The music was very appropriate and suited the atmosphere.  it wasnt loud, and the instrumental rockabilly tunes were adding to the atmosphere.    all of this for under $30 at a breakfast place. i would have had less of a well rounded and fulfilling experience if i were dining out for dinner and dropping $100.    so when you see the line out the door, go ahead and wait the 20 minutes.  its well worth it.

BEST GRITS EVER!!!! I work nearby and am constantly tempted to sneak over on my break just for some grits and a biscuit with the tasty apple butter sauce! I have yet to have anything that I dislike here, but I mainly stick with the breakfast foods, cause breakfast is the best. The Only food item I would say I wouldn't order again os the oatmeal based pancakes. They are very dense, heavy and tasteless unless you eat it smothered in syrup or with a mouthful of peaches. But the grits... get the grits.

Yummmm!! I took family here this past Monday while they were in town because we are from up north and I've heard this is the best place in Charlotte to get grits.  They weren't lying.. this place was so good! I got the grits of course and also a plate of there French toast with a raspberry drizzle! To dieeee for. =) On top of that the service was great too, very friendly. And the restaurant has a great look to it.  Ill be back.

The Food was semi-decent. I was so excited to try your biscuits because you are called the Flying Biscuit for goodness sakes. But unfortunately your biscuits weren't all they were talked up to be. When I received my meal, which I had order Egg-Ordinary which comes with the famous biscuits. The biscuits were quite doughy. So that was such a let down. But I still had a little hope in your food,so  I ate your grits which were outstanding. Even though your Biscuit s weren't the best. Your grits made up for it.

The Flying Biscuit is a chain, but I don't hold that against it. This is easily one of my favorite breakfast spots in Charlotte.  On weekend mornings, there is typically a small crowd waiting outside, but I've never had to wait long. There are a few tables out front, a cute, cheerful dining room (you can sit at the counter if you like), and a covered deck or porch out back with additional seating.  Service has always been friendly and attentive, but the real reason I keep coming back is the food. Every single breakfast I've eaten here has been excellent (they do serve lunch and dinner, but I'm so in love with their breakfasts, I see no reason to stray). Pancakes, French toast, scrambles and omelets--all of them are great, and so are the grits, potatoes, chicken sausage, and/or fresh fruit you can get with them.   Then, of course, there's the biscuits. They're great on their own, but do yourself a favor and spread some cranberry apple butter on top.

Pleasantly surprised!  Went to the other location last year and it was okay...  This time the food and service were both amazing!!  Love the biscuits, grits, French toast and the kids loved their quesadillas!  We had a great time, and will definitely be back!
Good food. Amazing apple butter for the biscuits. Your typical diner food with a slight creative flair. I drank that apple butter, it was that good.

We went to the original Flying Biscuit Cafe on occasion when we lived in Atlanta, and were excited to try this location in Charlotte.  Since this summer, we have eaten here four or more times, and actually prefer this location over Atlanta's.  Despite the distance from our house, FBC is now on our regular rotation for Saturday breakfast!  We've tried a few different menu items -  Biscuit, Eggs, and Gravy, Egg-Ceptional Eggs, Flatiron Steak and Eggs, and Meggxican Wrap.  The biscuit and chicken sausage gravy is my favorite, and they will gladly add cheese to the scrambled eggs upon request.  I can never finish the plate, the portion is so large!  Their grits are also fantastic, and I can always find room to finish those!  We only wish the black bean cakes in the Egg-Ceptional eggs were made a little thinner and crispier.  (I'm thinking of West Egg's black bean cakes in ATL as a point of comparison.)  Their Flatiron Steak and Eggs is very good, and one of my husband's favorites, along with the spicy Meggxican Wrap.     Service is always friendly and extremely fast.  The interior is larger than it appears, and we've always been seated quickly.  FBC has two patios - one in front facing the parking lot, and one larger one in the back (facing the quieter back parking area).  The back patio is larger and more comfortable...IF you can get a seat that's not in the direct sun.  They really need to install an awning to protect the outer tables from direct sunlight!  I appreciate that FB offers espresso drinks.  While expensive, their cappuccinos and lattes are pretty good.    If you haven't tried Flying Biscuit, you should!

Huge disappointment.   -Service was realllllly slow. Overall it was a 1.5 hour breakfast for 2 people once we were seated. We waited over 15 minutes my credit card back after giving it to the waitress and eventually went inside to find it. I think this is partly due to being understaffed.   -We sat outside and they leave their maple syrup on the tables. Bees were EVERYWHERE. The hostesses were swatting them and spraying them with whatever they clean the tables with.  -The biscuits are terrible. I would think if you have "biscuit" in your name and they are included with every meal they would be decent. They are dry and flour-y with sugar sprinkled on top. Any fast food restaurant has better biscuits.  The blueberry pancakes were pretty good as were the grits, but in the end it wasn't worth the wait and hassle.

I tried.  I really really tried to like Flying Biscuit.  :(  This place is always packed and people have left it pretty good reviews.  I think I'm the exception to the rule.  I've been here several times as I keep saying "I'll give it another shot. I'll go mid-week".....anddddddd it's the same not so grand experience for me.  :(    Let me tell you what I do like:  1) I like the location.  It's in Park Road Shopping Center which is close to home.  Check 2) I like the staff.  Although they are COMPLETELY slammed at peek hours, they always seem to make me smile and laugh and they're good. 3) The apple butter is heavenly 4)Mimosa pours are HUGE.  5) those biscuits tho   What I don't like and why I give it 2 stars: 1) Every time and I mean every time...I come here, My food order is COLD.  I even order it differently so they'll have to make it fresh.  :( 2)  They seem to always forget to seat us.  This is a popular place and they are slammed...I get that...but how you skip over our name when we see you mark it down the last several times we've been here is crazy.   3) on top of the food being cold, it's just not fresh.  My scrambled eggs are overcooked, the pancakes are hard and stale...it's just not good food.    So...I think this last visit has made me decide to break-up with Flying Biscuit when it comes to going here for the food.  I'll come for the coffee and mimosas and biscuits...but not the food.  (sorry..don't hate me!)
Great breakfast spot even though there is always a hungry mob on weekends and long wait. The.best.grits!

The food was not memorable. I had some kind of eggs with a biscuit, they have cutesy names, the biscuit was hard and inedible, even after soaking it in grits. The server that I explained this to told me she would ' tell them in the back' but never replaced my biscuit. The service, in general, is terribly lacking. Twice I have been there and twice told that my silverware was filthy because of the dishwasher. I am told this is a great place to eat. My experience tells me differently. Still, if you are an adventurous hipster you may well like the atmosphere and hip disservice. Enjoy.

Oh man this food is delicious!! We were in town for a concert and wanted a delicious breakfast. Boy did this place live up to the expectations! The grits and biscuits were so good. Coffee was tasty. Service was good, the host was the best.

Awesome twist on southern breakfast food!  Nothing on the menu was fried (from what we could tell) and they used turkey instead of pork products.  The food was excellent and the service was the same.  I cant remember what they called my dish, but it was supposed to be cajun (or something spicy), and it didnt quite have as much kick as I would have liked.  My wife had the biscuits and gravy and it was amazing!  Definitely a great place to eat!

Delllllish! This place is super casual, very trendy/hipster, draws a huge crowd and is soooo worth the wait! The grits are literally something you dream about and they know how to make their flavors work!! I'd say hands down try brunch here!!

This restaurant is always consistent and familiar. The service is awesome and you just always feel at home here.  The brunch is what I've been here for.  Everything is worth trying...there's nothing that I would tell you to stay away from.  The biscuits of course..while not really being able to fly, are a wonderful fluffy deliciousness.  The restaurant is slightly on the small side and there is chance for a wait.  It is uniquely decorated and there is plenty to look at while waiting.  ****In response to Chris S.....I just feel the menu could be spiced up a little.  Maybe more app choices or even small plates would be cool.  I have nothing bad to say about he current menu..but maybe a weekly or seasonal special? Something different to try.****

I've always heard great things about The Flying Biscuit, but my personal experience wasn't anything special. I met up with a friend for Sunday brunch and was seated immediately. The menu is expansive for a place that serves only breakfast all day. Although there were numerous options, I ended up ordering the Shrimp and Grits. The grits were great, already infused with butter, milk for a creamy texture. However, I thought the ingredients that accompanied the shrimp would be better suited for a pizza. The sauce was heavily tomato based and there wasn't much else aside from tomatoes that was impactful on the flavor. It tasted fine, but I feel other vegetables and another sauce would have been a better compliment to the shrimp. The service here is spectacular and the prices are reasonable, with most choices falling below $10.
I'll start off by saying delicious!  no Dr. Pepper or Mr. Pibb, was the only downfall to me.

Nestled in the middle of Park Road shopping center, Flying Biscuit is definitely a place to try. Once you walk in, you can't help but smile from all the colorful decor on the walls. They have quite the extensive breakfast and lunch menu, so there is something for everyone here.   I ordered the Southern Benedict, which is pimento cheese, poached egg and hollandaise sauce on a homemade biscuit. This was quite flavor packed, and a little on the spicy side. I'm not sure where the spice came from, and it was almost too much for me, but my breakfast date thought it was perfect. I got it with their creamy, dreamy grits and they most definitely lived up to their name! I highly recommend them if you're a grits fan. Also, each table has a squeeze bottle of apple butter to go with their biscuits, which is another added bonus for this spot.

I have been here multiple times, and never leave, wanting to return.   First, the food is usually great! The menu is good! There biscuits Benedict is perfection! However, that is only if your food arrives warm. Sometimes, it is warm, but seems stale.   Service is terrible. I have had to refill my own drinks, hunt down servers, etc. one time, a server showed up with a tray of drinks, set them down, and said "I don't know where these go," and walked away.   The Bloody Mary is disgusting.

One of my favorite breakfast spots!  Their biscuits are of course amazing, don't forget the jelly with them!  You can't go wrong with their omelets.  I recently ordered their steak and eggs and it was delicious!  I would definitely go back and it is a good spot to take family to as well.
High quality and creative dishes. I have been there a few times and the "Spicy Shrimp Quesadilla" is my favorite and I am not into spicey food.
Typical Southern style breakfast. The biscuits with apple sauce, is something I relished, other than the omelette and oat pancakes.
I stopped here for a quick late breakfast/ early lunch. I enjoyed the food as well as the service. My meal was delicious. They had some of the best grits you'll ever eat. Check them out!

We visited for Saturday brunch from out of town.  My husband really enjoyed the chicken sausage gravy and biscuits!  I had the Egg-ceptional Eggs, two eggs served over black bean cakes, tomatillo sauce, sour cream and feta.  Very flavorful and tasty!  The grits were pretty good, but as someone who doesn't get grits often I'm not picky.   The atmosphere is fun and quirky, service was efficient.  It's tucked in to a shopping plaza with plenty of parking.  Thought about going back during my stay but wanted to try as many places as I could before leaving. Solid breakfast!

I have heard good things about this place so I was excited to try it out. I love biscuits and this place serves an amazing one. First off it is huge. My husband loves the crunchy outside and I am a big fan of the gooey middle and this one does both. They had a cranberry apple butter sauce in a squeeze bottle on the table that was pretty good with the biscuit. Just a note, this biscuit is on the sweet side if you like more savory biscuits probably will not be for you.   I ordered the EGG-STRAORDINARY BREAKFAST - two eggs, creamy dreamy grits and oven-roasted "moon dusted" potatoes. Got my eggs over-hard so nothing special. I have never been a big fan of grits, but these were to die for.  No idea if they are good or not, but for me the first time I could eat a whole bowl of grits. No clue what made them so yummy to me, but I was blown away. Now the "moon dusted" potatoes on the other hand were also nothing special. I am guessing the "moon dust" is extra salt because they were super salty and I should have requested no dust for me.  Live and Learn.  My dining partner got the OVEN FRIED GREEN TOMATO BLT and it looked pretty good also, big portions, colorful. The whole wheat bun looked amazing.  I would highly recommend this place to people. I have heard it gets insane on the weekend, so we went early lunch time on a Friday. We got a table right away and our food came out quickly.

The menu has GF next to the items that are well, gluten free! Its a nice change to not have to ask about every single thing and worry, plus you can get breakfast anytime and who doesn't love that ( you know who you are).   A big bonus is that I also don't eat pork, so bacon is a no-No for me, but never fear, they have Turkey bacon!!! And chicken sausage, so I was ecstatic to have eggs and bacon along with my family and not think about eating a pig.  Some of their staff I think are a bit young and not as professional some others, sup watch put for those, they aren't bad, just a bit ditzy and distant, not as atentative as they should be to your needs.

I absolutely LOVE this place.  This has probably been my 10th time eating at the Flying Biscuit.  The first one I ever went to was in Atlanta in Midtown.  I'm glad they branched out to Charlotte a few years back.  I seriously can't find anything I don't like on the menu.  The Roasted Hummus Wrap is to die for.  You also get those "moon-dusted" potatoes as your side with that yummy fresh Biscuit and that apple butter.  YUM.  On this recent visit I got the Veggie Omelette with a side of fruit, and of course the yummy biscuit. The Flying Biscuit is very different than other restaurants and has its own distinct feel.  This location on Park Rd is my favorite because it is a Huge Space.  The other Flying Biscuit locations are very small, and when there busy (which tends to be often) you usually have to wait forever to get seated.  The Park Rd location also has a huge patio in the back, and also a small patio in the front for extra seating when its warm.  If you haven't ate at the Flying Biscuit I definitely recommend going.  You won't regret it.
The grits is heaven and I'm a southern girl. The biscuits my aunt makes far better. Definitely worth it and breakfast served all day - so have a late night then go have brunch.

We sat at the bar to avoid the wait,  though we drank coffees, seeing the bartender make drinks, i can say they are generous (to say the least) when making mimosas. Who needs a flute when you have a 16oz cup?   The staff are delightful, and I really liked the fried green tomatoes. The breakfast ordered (egg-ceptional dish), however,  wasn't anything exceptional....But, this may be just what we ordered.   Nonetheless, based on the fantastic  service, and great Yelp reviews, I would definitely come back... but would probably order something different.

I was very impressed. I was so happy to find a healthier option- I had eggs with veggies. They gave me a side of potatoes, grits, and a biscuit. The potatoes where nothing special. But oh man! Those grits and bisects are a must! I'm not even a fan of grits but I really liked these grits! Definitely a great mom and pop shop to check out! The coffee was good as well. They had a dark roast. Normally restaurant coffee doesn't impress me, but it was a solid cup of joe
This was a great breakfast spot close to our hotel! The biscuits were amazing and the grits were the best ever.
I have been eating grits all my life. My first table food after baby formula was probably grits. The Flying Biscuit cafe has the best, creamest, cheeisest grits....Hands down!

My coworkers brought me out here for brunch one Friday morning.  Man.. was I pleased with their choice.  This place ROCKED!!  The menu including about 50 different omelets, and they allowed me to mix and match any of their sides.  I heard the creamy dreamy grits are to die for, but I got the home fried potatoes and was far from disappointed with the decision.  The biscuit was the best part (it better be, its in the title).  It also comes with a side of apple butter that I devoured.   I got the Piedmont Omelete and it was HUGE and scrumptious  The only negative side is that the wait can be crazy.  That's a good sign though, right?  I came back the very next day to bring the Mrs there and it was an hour wait at 11am.  Yikes!  i would definitely suggest giving this place a try during some off hours.    Enjoy!  -Ian M.

Great southern breakfast! Food was delicious, waitstaff super friendly. We were seated within 10 minutes of arriving without a reservation on a Sunday and received are food just as promptly. Would definitely recommend to out of towners looking for some good eats!

Recently moved to the Charlotte area and was in desperate need for some good brunch. As an Elite Yelper I went straight to Yelp and found this amazing place after several searches.  The initial reason I chose this establishment is bc I had a massive craving for Shrimp & Grits. The night before went to a Louisiana style restaurant and ordered the Shrimp & Grits which was different than I was use to lol. Thank you Flying Biscuit cause the Shrimp & Grits were amazing and delicious. I also ordered the Steak & Eggs which came with grits which was also great. I ordered it rare and it came out well done so that's something they could work on.  The service was top notch and I never had to ask for anything since our waitress was so attentive. For those of you looking for a quick mimosa with brunch, guess what they have mimosas and their not half bad.   As for the decor, it's a bit out dated so it could use a little sprucing up but that doesn't affect the food. Very diverse and great food so be prepared to wait about 20-30 mins but it's soooo worth the wait!

Flying Biscuit.  Not fast enough.  We arrived peak hours, on a Sunday afternoon, with a party of about 10.  We were seated pretty quickly, considering the crowd loitering around outside and our size.  But our service was less than par.  We had at least three of the managers come serve us our beverages, while we baked in the heat of the sun (although we did request an outside seat).  And our server took too long, to take our drink orders and then to take our food orders.  Other than service, the food was delicious.  I was thoroughly surprised by the sweet biscuits.  And then, topped with chicken sausage gravy, this added a completely new spin on the meaning of biscuits and gravy.  Not my favorite, but definitely interesting.  And the best of all, those creamy, dreamy grits!  Who can forget such a delectable treat!  Although, they said there was cheese mixed in, it was not nearly enough for my satisfaction.  Definitely will be a repeat, unless the service continues to be slower than molasses.

While in the area I wasn't sure where to eat so I did as I usually will and scoured Yelp. The Flying Biscuit has lived up to its reputation and served me quite possibly the best breakfast I have ever been served.  - Quirky Interior - Inexpensive Prices - Friendly Service - Flavor Packed Food - Variety in Menu - Easy-to-Find Location  I wasn't sure what to expect from the shopping mall exterior but when I walked up to see a friendly face at the door and corn hole boards for those that wait, I was pleased.  I started off with a Large OJ ($2.99) and while the size wasn't what I expected, it did taste like fresh squeeze which is much better than paying the Gallon price for a cup of Minute Maid.  I ordered the sausage gravy, eggs and biscuits ($9.29). The grits are so good! Everything was packed with flavor.  My wife ordered the Turkey hash ($9.25). It was So delicious! The meat was so tender and packed with flavor. I asked for tomatillo sauce on side and it just boosted the delicious factor for me.  I would highly recommend you stop here for a few bites!

we drove from cornelius to charlotte to try Flying biscuit as there are so few breakfast options in Lake Norman area. Wow worth the drive. most amazing biscuits and gravy EVER (chicken gravy)- delish. Everything was good. Worth driving for a memorable meal-
It's hard to get breakfast wrong and the breakfast is certainly decent though nothing spectacular. What is odd to me is that the biscuits (their namesake) are just not good and the reason for review.
I love this place they always deliever my food was Awesome as was the service.

My boyfriend and I came in for a late brunch on a Sunday. It was very quiet and they seemed to be recuperating after the rush. We were seated promptly, everything was clean, and we had a sweet and attentive server. It was our first time coming to The Flying Biscuit so she was patient with us taking some time to make our decisions. I appreciate the gluten free choices listed clearly on the menu, great selection of food to choose from. Both of our entrees were made well and we had no complaints.

First place I went to go visit during my business trip to North Carolina. I had hoped to end it here as well, but I woke up late. I am actually writing this at CLT, sitting on one of them white rocking chairs. Man, as I am thinking about what to write for this place, my mouth is already salivating..  My girlfriend went to Florida for law school and told me that I HAD to go to one of these places. My goodness it was good. A great way to say: WELCOME TO THE SOUTH (I know NC is a debatable southern state, but this restaurant surely is).  I got the one with sausage biscuit, layered over by scrambled eggs and grits on the side. I never had grits before and it took some "acquiring" to do for me to enjoy it. BUT man the sausage biscuit with the scrambled eggs on top is something to DIEEEEE FORRRR! I don't think I need to do any explaining but, to say to go get it, and get fat, like a true Southerner.  Nothing up north has something like this. I want it now.

Food is really fantastic. Very impressed with the chicken sausage and the raspberry French toast. Grits, apple butter, eggs- all outstanding. Something here for everyone. The atmosphere is fun and we didn't have to wait because we went at 2pm.  Service was about a B so I can't give it 5 stars, but I will definitely return!

Went here at 11a on a Sunday. Wait was 10 mins.  Went with a table for 4. Sat outside, it was a beautiful day! I ordered their version of eggs benedict. Bacon was extra crispy, delicious! Don't understand the reason for the excessive amount of shredded cheese. Eggs were over cooked, not sure if they poach them or bake them? But the biscuit was to die for! Also, for not being a fan of grits,  they have their grits together! I would definitely be back wherever I'm in town.
Mmmmmm. The Flying Biscuit. It's my favorite breakfast place. Creamy dreamy grits and the biscuits are amazing. There is often a line but the service is fast and friendly.

The Biscuits are Flying, out of the window!  If you name your restaurant after a food, then you better be exceptional at preparing that item.  Sadly, that isn't the case here.  Growing up in the south, I have had countless opportunities to indulge in biscuits from restaurants as well as homemade.  It upsets me that the flour taste of the biscuits here were very heavy and they were extremely dry.  Having eaten here 3 times now, I can safely say that they are great at reproducing the awful biscuit recipe.  I should not have to drown my biscuit in strawberry jelly and butter just to choke it down.  It should be buttery and moist, and full of southern charm.  I digress....  The vegetarian options are extremely limited, but if you eat eggs then it is okay.  I had the over-easy eggs on top of a black bean cake.  It was very tasty!!  They do sweet tea VERY well!  After our meal, we sprung for a cup of coffee because that's a southern requirement.  I am equally sad to report that the coffee tasted burned and we were merely drinking coffee for the sake of it.  There was zero enjoyment.  Thankfully a french bakery opened in the same plaza so they provided us with a great cup of coffee after breakfast.  The place is always packed, which would indicate they are doing something right.  But, they could be so much better if they focused on the details a little more.    Service is fast, floors are clean-ish, and the door host is highly energetic.  I would go back again under special circumstances.... BETTER BISCUITS!

Excellent!  My first time here, met for an early morning business meeting.  Service left a little to be desired but was still above average, otherwise, would have been 5-stars.  Food was great, biscuit was phenomenal!  Missed the apple butter until the end, so will be back soon.  A definite must try for anyone!
Meh. Everything was just ok. Do not go here when it's cold outside. We were seated right by the door whi was constantly opening. Freezing does not make for an enjoyable meal.

Came to FB first time with my husband for brunch on Saturday and I was impressed. It was a little packed but we were seated right away. Staffs are very friendly and attentive.   We felt like something breakfast-y so we ordered pumpkin pancakes and full size french toast added two fluffy biscuits (it is a must!). The food came out pretty fast. The biscuits were really fluffy and huge. We absolutely loved them! We also got Shrimp & grits and honestly it tasted really good. Not too creamy nor salt. What a delicious breakfast meal.   A must try if you are in the area.
For a place called the flying biscuit, their biscuits aren't so sky high. Chick-fil-a has better biscuits in my opinion.   However, their chicken sausage gravy and grits are both amazing.

I had been to the location in the Raleigh/Durham area in the past so I tried the Charlotte location once I realized they had one. It was crowded but there was no wait and we were seated immediately. Additionally, the service was good and the waiter prompt. The biggest thing I noticed was how quickly the food came out. We honestly waited less than 10 minutes after we ordered for our food. I had the shrimp and grits and it was good. They use a tomato based sauce, which isn't my favorite but it was still flavorful. Shockingly, the worst part of the meal was the biscuit. Plenty of parking as the restaurant is in a shopping center.

The ambiance was cool. Very colorful. The omelette was excellent and so was the buscuit it came with. The service was great. The only thing was their buttermilk pancakes weren't great. If you're looking for the premier breakfast restaurants go to the Yolk in Rock Hill. If not, this is a solid 2nd.

Always a friendly place with some very nice homey foods,everything's got a twist here. Black bean cakes cakes are pretty decent but their eggs dishes are excellent. A lot of familes with children stagger in service is always friendly and courteous a great place for breakfast, lunch or Dinner. Breakfast is pricey, lunch is comparable but Dinner is very reasonable. They have great cocktails and a few craft beers as well as wines.

Had the shrimp and grits and it was good. The shrimp was cooked perfectly and the grits are the top of the list. Mom giving it a 3 star as the sanitation score was very low at an 83%.   I will definitely try it again if they increase the sanitation scores.

For some reason I feel like this place has gone downhill....fast. I used to  love them, or maybe I was just ignorant of all the other yummy places around but this last visit was majorly disappointing.  The biscuits are still pretty good...not served as warm and they were a little more dry.  My go-to meal is the organic oatmeal pancakes with peaches.  This past time they were dry, almost overcooked and bland.    The eggs were okay but not fluffy, the chicken sausage was greasy and chewy, the fruit was primarily honey dew, etc etc.  I could go on and on.    The service was okay but honestly, not super efficient or friendly.  They were packed on Saturday and they are in a great location but I'm over them.  I just don't think the quality is that great.  Too many other spots popping up around town.

The first time in was because I knew they served breakfast all day, and ever since then I haven't really strayed from the breakfast menu, no matter what meal I actually should be having.   The omelets are large, the biscuits are yum (but are substantially better before they start to sit out too long post breakfast-rush), and my eggs are always cooked nicely. My serious gripe with the place is the wait time, no matter if I'm one of five tables or one of twenty five - it always takes what seems like FOREVER to get my food. And of course I can't even get a water refill while I wait, for a place so open the service staff has found some really good places to hide!  That being said I've still kept the flying biscuit on my list, because their food is pretty good (so far I think the cajun scramble is my favorite) and you don't have to worry about your eggs arriving in a pool of grease like some other breakfast all day establishments.
I've never liked biscuits until I tried theirs. I had the Benedict and the biscuit was amazing also try the grits they are something else.

Wasn't super impressed with the whole meal but I do want to say that my biscuit was delicious!! Perfectly done with a little crisp on the outside but nice in the middle. Tried it with the Apple Butter & it was a great combination!  The service was good and there weren't many people there in the middle of the morning on a Wednesday.   If you're looking for breakfast option you may be able to find something better but this place is pretty solid with a good variety and good food.

I'm going to say this...   I'd been wanting to visit The Flying Biscuit for a while.  Seen the great reviews so I wanted in as well.   Decided to stop in before an appointment so I was kinda crunched for time but I was at war with my stomach and guess what? It won!  I was greeted promptly and seated. I requested a cup of joe and a water. After tussling with sugar packets ( I despise sugar packets. Get sugar dispensers already.)   I ordered the shrimp and grits. It was ok. The shrimp were cooked just right and the grits were tasty and creamy but the chunks of tomato I can do without. I think Midnight Diner has spoiled me with their shrimp and grits. Along with my fish there was a biscuit. A HARD biscuit. I started to ask for butter but in this case it wouldn't have helped. I slathered the jam that was provided inside the biscuit. Honestly, I wouldn't sell biscuits that hard. Biscuits should be soft and WARM....  Anywho, I'd give The Flying Biscuit another try minus the biscuit.
Probably the best breakfast I've ever had! Their biscuits benedict and their oatmeal pancakes are awesome!
Good food - very prompt service - wide variety on the menu - food is just ok, but the staff is very friendly and very accomodating - give it a try, you might see some things you like

I was impressed. I use Yelp to help me chose places to eat since I travel so much. The pictures were so helpful. I chose this place because of the pictures and number of check ins. I got the high flyer; oatmeal pancake (don't add syrup) egg white and apple turkey sausage patty with potatoes. It was so good I had to come back the next day. My boyfriend got steak and eggs. It's a huge amount of food for a great cost. Would def recommend Flying Biscuit to others. There's a wait which further lets you know the food is good

If you are looking for a good breakfast, with some standard items, bacon and eggs, to southern style options, shrmip and grits, The Flying Biscuit is somewhere you should go. Although there can be a wait on Saturday and Sunday mornings, it moves pretty quickly and I find the food worth the wait. The biscuits are always served warm, with a side apple butter, and a sprinkle of cooked sugar on top, my favorite part of the biscuit... As for the other options, the veggie omelett is my favorite. A three egg omelett with peppers, onions, spinach, mushrooms and swiss cheese. Perfect! I also love the chicken sausage.  Note: It does have a spicy kick so be prepared. And, I am not a grits fan so I always ordered the potatoes. However, I few weeks ago I decided to give them a try and loved them. They were creamy and not what I expected. I have ordered them ever seen.  Although the food is great the service can be hit or miss. They do like to "turn tables" so servers can seem rushed. And, they have so many tables at once you have to grab someone or be patient. However, it hasn't hindred my visits, and I know I will be back..maybe even this weekend.

Brunch is the most important meal of the day, so my friends and I searched for the best place in the area and settled on the Flying Biscuit.  They'd been there in the past and had great things to say about the homemade biscuits and apple butter.  We arrived at noon on Saturday and the place was packed. There was no where to seat our large party so we ended up on the patio at the rear of the restaurant.  For the most part we were alone with the funky hanging art and water spritzing fans.  The restaurant seems to be a bit cramped, so I wasn't upset.  Looking at the menu I had a tough time deciding what to order.  There were so many options, both sweet and savory.  Since I wanted to try a bit of everything, I went for the High Flyer.  I had no idea what I was getting myself into. So much food!  I had never tried chicken sausage before, but I was quite impressed.  The grits were absolutely delicious and creamy.  My favorite thing overall was the oatmeal pancake.  It was thick and fluffy and perfectly matched with the peach compote.  Everyone was happy with their brunch selection.  The only issues with our meal were the slight snafus by our server.  Because we were out back, she seemed to forget about us every so often.  My friend had ordered an appetizer, but it was not brought out until he had reminded the waitress toward the end of our meal.  Not a huge ordeal considering how much other food we had already devoured.    If I were in the area again, I'd definitely return.  There are so many options to try, I'm sure I'd never get the same thing twice.

LOVE LOVE LOVE IT!  The first time we stepped foot into Flying Biscuit was in Atlanta.  Whenever we visit our friend in ATL we would always go to the Midtown location.  We'd get there around 8:00am, put in our name down, and wait...45min - 1hr later we'd get seated.  It was always totally worth the wait!   Now Charlotte has 2 locations!  If you get there after 8-9am on the weekends, you will definitely have to wait, maybe 15-30 min.  I love the eclectic menu.  They have some traditional items (steak and eggs, omlettes, and biscuits and gravy) and some fun nontraditional ones (black bean cakes, scrambled tofu, and orange scented french toast).  Obviously, they are known for their biscuits.  They are not like the normal flakey buttery biscuits you may be used to.  They have a scone-like consistency, solid and firm on the outside and soft on the inside.  The cranberry apple butter is to die for.  It's sweet yet tangy! YUMMY!  I was never a fan of grits until I tried them there.  They are the creamiest grits in the world!  Now every time I go out for breakfast somewhere else, I always want to get grits, but it's never ever as good as FB.  So I stopped trying them at other places.  Sorry other breakfast guys...Flying Biscuit has the BEST grits EVER!  The only reason I gave 4 not 5 stars is the service.  The Park Rd location has extremely slow service.  Every other time we go the service is so slow, even when they are not busy.  I took my family there for breakfast and we got seated before 2 other tables around us.  The other tables had their drinks and appetizer orders before we were even greeted by our waitress.  We complained and the manager gave us a complimentary fried green tomato appetizer (which was really good).  Hopefully they will work on it.

I love this place! It was about a 15 minute wait to get in at noon, which is not bad. Once seated the service was quick to get drinks and take our order. I tried something different for me, the southern scramble, it was awesome!! Eggs, onions, greens, ham I think, and cheese. Yummy! My daughter had the biscuits and gravy. She really like it, but beware it is a large portion. I tasted her biscuits and gravy also and really loved the gravy. Super tasty. The only thing that I was not crazy about, and this is strictly a preference, the biscuits were very thick and heavy. I like mine light and fluffy. But the apple butter they have sitting on the table, fantastic! One other note, the shopping center is very busy, so you may have to park far in the parking lot. But well worth it.

Was really hopeful given the reviews, but the only thing I liked was my latte. The biscuits and gravy come with eggs on top and a side of grits. So basically a huge pile of brown food- appetizing? I think not. It just wasn't good, big miss for me.

I discovered Flying Biscuit during a recent trip to Charlotte and visited twice. It's a delicious, creative breakfast spot (they have lunch dishes too, but I stuck with the former), low key and casual with easy prices. The food is a little inconsistent - biscuits were better the first time I visited than the second, when they were a tad undercooked - but the grits are to die for and their pimento cheese is delicious. Will definitely be back!

Flying Biscuit is still excellent for breakfast. I had the Turkey Hash, which was a pile of fried potatoes, a big portion of what was probably turkey pot roast, two eggs over medium and cheese on top. With a big biscuit. This was a very large portion and it tasted great. I was very pleased with it.  Been here a few times and enjoy going back. It is VERY busy on the weekends, not as much during the week at breakfast time.

We didn't have to wait for long. We were greeted right away. They were super busy but our server made us feel like we were at home. My mom and I both ordered the piedmont omelette. Both dishes came out pretty quickly to my surprise. I was a little disappointed with my food though. I have heard so many good things about The Flying Biscuit. I guess they cook the Turkey bacon with the eggs?( I have never seen that technique before). Normally the ingredients are stuffed inside of the egg... I believe because of the fact that they were trying to cook the turkey bacon thoroughly it over cooked my eggs. My eggs were definitely well done and brown all over. There moon dusted potatoes were ok. The service was awesome though.

I have been here once a few years ago and I can tell you I could still taste the grits l couldn't stop thinking about them, so naturally when my friends wanted to have breakfast for dinner here I said yes. We started with the pimento cheese and oven fried green tomatoes, both were delicious. My main course I ordered the Shrimp scramble and added the jalapeño bacon mixed in with half grits and half potatoes for the side. The grits were just as I remembered and the potatoes were perfect. The jalapeño bacon was so good I was I just got it by itself because I was digging through the scramble for it. The scramble itself was okay but I wouldn't order it again the bacon did set it off though and gave it more favor. And it looked to be like 2 shrimp cut up inside of it. The service was fast and on point with making sure our drinks were full and we were doing alright.
Well worth the wait!  Our waitress was SUPER nice and funny, prompt and attentive, made us all laugh. Food delicious, portions were abundant.

When I my mother and sister decided on a Girls' Brunch while we visited Charlotte, I looked to my trusty Yelp app to find the perfect restaurant.  And boy, was The Flying Biscuit Cafe a great choice!    It was a crowded Sunday morning there, but that's to be expected when the food is so good.  I started with a Chai Tea and worked my way up to a Latte, both of which were delicious!  I tasted each dish on the table and it they all exceeded my expectations.  I wish they had a brunch tasting menu!  :)  Make sure you try the biscuits with cranberry-apple butter.  The creamy dreamy grits are also a winner!

Food, great. Service, terrible. Our waitress was Monique. She was not attentive in the least. I literally watched her talking in the back of the restaurant while my boyfriend and I sat with empty glasses. His food arrived cold (which indicates that it was sitting for a while, most likely). Nor was she very friendly.  Do yourself a favor and go to the other location.

Flying Biscuit is a great go to for brunch.  They have a lot of options and good coffee. It's become very popular since opening so expect a wait during peak times but it is worth it. And if it's a long wait they have been known to bring out coffee for everyone to sip on. Also don't be afraid to sit at the bar - it's laid out very well and I never mind sitting there.  Service has always been good.

The first time I had anything from  The Flying Biscuit was at a YELP event, with their shrimp and grits. I came back for at least 5-6 more cups, the stuff was amazing.  I finally got the chance to go and have breakfast here (not a huge breakfast fan), but I really enjoyed my self. The restaurant had a little but of a line out the door but we were seated within 10-15 minutes of arriving. I love that mustache guy   Service was good I had a giant pumpkin spice latte, it was HUGE! Followed by a  Clifton Omelette: Three large farm fresh eggs stuffed with goat cheese and mushrooms, topped with warm tomato coulis and basil, served with creamy dreamy grits  It was a lot of food after that latte and the Biscuits are amazing and huge -  had to take left overs home!   While it seems a little pricey for breakfast, you are getting some quality food that is unique and tasty! We'll be back!

Love this place.  They have good coffee (imperative to brunch) and a mouth-watering menu.  The grits are by far the creamiest most delicious grits I've ever had and their breakfast plates always leave you full and happy.  The atmosphere is fun and we always get a seat quickly.  Plus they have a sweet patio out back!

We love coming here for brunch. Be sure to call in if your party is bigger than 2, it's normally a 10 minute wait for a couple of people. It's always packed so service can get a little backed up. We sat at the patio yesterday, they have heaters, don't worry. I prefer to sit inside though, better to people watch while you wait for food.  I like to start off with a hot chocolate and those heavenly love cakes. The love cakes are soft but flavorful black bean cakes smothered in tasty salsa verde and topped with a dollop of sour cream and feta cheese crumbles. This is literally my favorite item on the menu and it doesn't make you feel bad for eating it. The chicken sausage gravy is my runner up fav menu item, it's so good with everything, especially home fries.  I normally order the smoked salmon scramble or the souther biscuit Benedict if I want to get crazy full. I only really like the Benedict if I take it home and reheat it. The salmon scramble has this amazing cream cheese and dill sauce. We've also got the side of grilled Mac and cheese, it's ok but needs some seasoning. The biscuits and huge and chalky, you will need gravy, butter, or jam to get through it.   Worth the wait, must try at least once.

Lately, the Mr and I have been referred to as "Brunch People." And that's a role that comes with a lot of responsibility. Saturday and Sunday mornings often turn into a "Where should we go for brunch?" discussion before I'm even out of bed.   Fact. It was Sunday morning and I was hungry. Moving from the "Oh, I could eat" to "I am going to punch someone if I don't get food immediately" state of mind. After running through the list of places   a) open for breakfast/brunch at 9am b) we hadn't tried in a while/ever c) were close to our home...  we settled on the dependable Flying Biscuit.   In my heart, when I'm hungry and I think of breakfast, there is nothing more satisfying than the perfectly executed PASTA, SAUSAGE & EGGS. Say what you will about the rest of the menu, but this is one dish that they get right every time. Given my dietary and lifestyle choices, I always ask them to substitute soysage for the sausage, which the kitchen obligingly does.  For this dish, expect creamy eggs with cheese, penne pasta, sausage (or soysage), spinach, mushrooms (and maybe a bit of onion) all scrambled together into a perfect melange of all that is breakfast.  Fire that up with an unbelievably tall and bizarrely sweet biscuit topped with a squirt of apple butter and a side of creamy dreamy grits and I swear, it will be worth the 10 minute wait on a weekend.  Their coffee is notably not the worst I've had.   Other interesting, veggie-friendly things to try: - Fried green tomatoes (a twist on the traditional) - Orange scented french toast (order extra anglaise -- trust me) - Clifton omelette (winner)  I'm sure their non-breakfast offerings are good, but I can't stray from my favorites.

Second time's the charm!  We showed up with the same party that we did for the first go-round (party of 10).  This experience was mucccchhh better...minus the wait, which was a lot longer than the first time.  First off, our server Joseph was awesome. Our last server was meh but Joseph was TERRIFIC!!  Egg-ceptional eggs was terrific. Biscuits were much better.  Our wait was long but that just meant more time spent with our Navy BFFs before we were separated by oceans and countries.  Thanks to Joseph and the improved quality of food, we'd definitely go back.

I just went here last week, and was I surprised! The place is a lot bigger inside than I expected. Ended up getting the tofu and taters salad since it was closer to lunch and it still came with a biscuit. Sooooo good!!! I'm not sure I will ever eat anything else there! A must go!
Great food and service, nuff said. I enjoyed the Piedmont omelette and creamy grits that are delicious and slightly different than classic grits. The biscuits are also outstanding.

This place is amazing!!  My favorite is that they offer a Guiness with expresso (I usually go for 2 shots myself) - the best morning beverage ever. They have delicious food too - great place for brunch.    Best Tip about this place: There is a back patio that is very nice and quiet!!
The flying biscuit has great breakfast and lunch options. Definitely the go to sunday breakfast spot.

First time, and I will be back. My husband and I stopped in for an early breakfast, and it was a southerner's breakfast dream. The southern style eggs Benedict was, hands down, the best thing I have eaten in a long time. Fluffy biscuit, pimento cheese, poached egg, turkey bacon, and hollandaise...this is refined country cookin' done right. The grits are better than my mama's and those three cheese Quaker grits that got me through college. Excellent food, excellent service, and excellent music in the background - nothing like Hall and Oates to start the day. Make this a to-do if you have yet to visit
biscuits and gravy, throw a poached egg on top. best in town

Eh, my first expierience here was just "ok".  After seeing many a Flying Biscuit without ever trying it, after living in Atlanta for several years, when the suggestion was made to go to Flying Biscuit for brunch I was looking forward to it.    I ordered the Steak n' Eggs w/ a substituted side of their grilled Mac n' Cheese and eggs scrambled with cheese.  Super healthy order.    The eggs were fine, what you would expect.    My steak was ordered rare and came out well-done.  They did promptly fix it and 10 mins. later I had my steak back while I was eating the rest of the food.  Overall taste of the steak was 4/5 stars, especially for a "breakfast" place.  Some of my friends were raving about the grilled Mac n' Cheese but I ordered it and wasn't impressed.  The grilled part of the grilled Mac n' Cheese makes it dry out a bit and have a strange "grill" flavor that is just not inherent to Mac n' Cheese in my book.  Overall, for $20 including tip, meal, and an iced latte - I've had way better brunches.  Would I try it again and order something different, sure but I'd probably stick with something more "traditonal".

If you're looking for a breakfast spot that falls in-between Bojangles and a brunch spot on east blvd this is your place.I wasn't aware that this FB was a chain. You can't really tell from the decor. Located in the park road shopping center, Flying Biscuit is filled with little tables and booths covered in bright sunflower table clothes.Our waitress was attentive and she never let my coffee run low. Major brownie points for that. I ordered the Pimento eggs Benedict, it was really great. It was different with the pimento and super filling. I would go ahead and order that again. Colin got this odd oatmeal pancake, I don't think he will get that again. Overall, if you're looking for a quick diner like breakfast place, give Flying Biscuit a try.

We came here based on Yelp reviews, unfortunately we were not impressed. We came for brunch on Sunday, thinking there would be a line out the door because this place was rated so well but it was empty. There were 4 other tables, that should have been our first sign but our hunger overtook our common sense.  The waiter was friendly but did not bother to mention his name. We ordered the eggstavaganza, a kids meal ( flyer I think it was called), hash and eggs,coffee, chai latte,and kids milk. No refills offered.  The food was at best described as eh. Absolutely nothing special, we actually didn't even finish our plates. We love trying quirky restaurants but this one missed the mark by a mile.  This restaurant is touted for its delicious healthy food options by fellow yelpers but that claim fell flat on its face. Service was lacking, no fresh squeezed orange juice, the chai latte tasted like they made it from a box of Tazo chai latte at best, chicken sausage and turkey bacon tasted like rubber, and the biggest disappointment of all were the biscuits! They were dry, dense and burned, completely inedible. Just my humble opinion but shouldn't a place called The Flying Biscuit have phenomenal biscuits?!   Quick tip, if you ever find yourself in a seedy section of Charlotte don't worry just have a few of these biscuits on hand..a few teenage mutant ninja turtle moves later and you can ninja chuck your assailant until they flee for their life.  The only saving grace was the grits.. Who would think.. this Yankee now likes grits!

Solid 4 stars goes to the Flying Biscuit Cafe.  Yes most of their items on their menu is a good bet for breakfast/brunch/lunch... but I think my favorite time to go is dinner.  1)  The place is not as busy and crazy and 2) who doesn't like breakfast for dinner??!!??  It's practically a staple at my house (especially when I moved out of my folks place and the main thing I knew how to cook were eggs).  I REALLY like the art on the walls.  I recognized a large piece from a local artist and I am sure most of the other pieces are probably local as well.  Good to promote the local art scene and makes for good breakfast for dinner conversation.  Everything I have tried thus far has been super delicious and well cooked.  It also helps that the items won't hurt the wallet/purse as bad - very comparable to other breakfast spots around town.  Bottom line:  watch out for weekend crowds, but this place is golden.
Omelet was great, biscuits were phenomenal but the grits were simply the best this 50 yo southern boy has ever had.

It's a nice place for breakfast if you're in the area, but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat there.  The staff is really friendly and helpful.  There is often a wait for a table on weekends.  I don't like their turkey bacon: it's not very meaty nor very flavorful.  The biscuits are nice, but certainly not the best I've ever had.  Overall, I think it's a bit pricey, and I take my business elsewhere.

Where do we start ? Another hot find in the Charlotte area. The Queen City is full of these hidden gems. We were initial almost discourage with the huge line outside but this was even more of a reason to give it a try (long line, must be good).  We were greet in a timely manner by nice gentleman. We waited roughly 15 to maybe 20 mins but boy wasn't the wait worth it.   Let's dive into the grub aka food (overall delicious). I ordered the southern scramble that consisted of all the mouth watering southern food (collard, applewood bacon, grits). The eggs were hands down amazing (fluffy, light and creamy). The collards and the bacon were a perfect match. The only thing that I would change were the onions that were a bit raw. However, this is not the best part yet!!  The grits!! (Creamy, buttery, smooth, and just simply mouth watering). The real MVP of this place were the grits.   The biscuits were good but really didn't see what all the hype was to be honest. They were a bit in the dry side but still good. Not taking anything away from this place.   (Maybe I was just blown away by the grits.)!!  Oh, let's not forget my wife food was amazing from what I gather from her empty plates. My wife ordered the meggixcan wrap which she loved.   The service was good, Claudia was quick and attentive. She was pretty busy but go figure right ? Amazing food equals busy place  Loved it.

This is my favorite breakfast spot in Charlotte! Unbelievably good food. The grits, the chicken sausage gravy, and the biscuits with apple butter is so good! Definitely check this place out if in Charlotte!

Me, Ben & James had to stop in and check out their breakfast, in a word...Wow! I had the salmon eggs benedict and it far exceeded my eggspectations!  Great coffee, great food and staff! Not bad for a franchise place.  It's get's busy so expect a wait if you don't get there early.  It's in the location where Elfrida's Florist used to be. It was one of the original tenants of Park Road for 52 years and closed in 2008.

I popped in and ordered shrimp and grits... Those grits are life! Creamy with excellent flavor I could eat them all day... The shrimp and sauce equally delicious :) Since I flew solo I sat at the counter and met the most interesting people! Foodies unite! Each dish comes with a biscuit and that biscuit was hot and fresh and not from a freezer! I WILL be back :)

I have never eaten anything here that wasn't outstanding. Cheese grits, eggs Benedict, and a mimosa.  typically a small wait on weekend mornings. I've never waited more than 20 minutes but, it's completely worth it.

I got the turkey hash with eggs over medium. It was a great mix of turkey, potato, egg, and cheese. The complimentary biscuits was fluffy and the apple butter that they had on the table was incredible. Don't miss the apple butter.

This Flying Biscuit was a bit difficult for our group to find in the shopping center.  When we arrived we saw that there was already a line outside.  Luckily we were able to bypass the waste by sitting at the little (coffee) bar that they have.  My friends said that they had great coffee but that may have just been the hangover talking.  I ordered the Cajun Chicken Scramble with an extra couple of their famous biscuits.  The scramble had egg, cajun-seasoned chicken, goat cheese, onions, and sun dried tomatoes with a warm cajun tomato sauce.  It was ok.  With all of those good flavorful ingredients I expected a LOT more flavor.  There was very little goat cheese mixed in and those bites were my favorite.  It didn't help that I feel like my order was sitting in "the window" for a few minutes too long.  The biscuits are very good.  BIG.  Fluffy on the inside with a nice outer crust.  I really liked the cranberry apple spread.  It had an excellent bite and wasn't super sweet.  Our sever was very pleasant and took very good care of us.  The inside of the restaurant is so bright and has a cheery feeling that was perfect on our raining Monday morning.  The service, the biscuits, and the ambiance got Flying Biscuit to 3 stars because my entree was just really disappointing.
